docs.lead_paragraph: Questions about Vice President Al Gore's honesty have emerged as a recurring motif of his contest with former Senator Bill Bradley for the Democratic presidential nomination. Mr. Bradley has angrily accused the vice president of a systematic effort to distort Mr. Bradley's record while whitewashing his own. The criticism of Mr. Gore has been harsh enough that President Clinton was asked about it today and offered a spirited defense of his vice president. ''My experience is that he is exceedingly honest and exceedingly straightforward,'' Mr. Clinton said at a news conference.

headline.main: Questions of Veracity Have Long Dogged Gore

docs.abstract: Questions about Vice Pres Al Gore's honesty have emerged during Democratic presidential campaign; Bill Bradley has accused Gore of systematic effort to distort Bradley's record while whitewashing his own; Pres Clinton says Gore has always been 'brutally honest' with him (M)

byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE with JOHN M. BRODER

docs.lead_paragraph: TAIZO KOMURASAKI has lived the quintessential Japanese life. A salaryman at a trading company that he joined straight out of college, he specialized in arranging financing for the company's activities. He retired, as is the norm in Japan, when he became eligible for his pension at age 60. That was two years ago. Like most Japanese men and women his age, Mr. Komurasaki had long planned to seek another job to keep himself busy. After all, he could expect to live another 17 years, according to actuarial tables; his health was good; and he felt that he could still contribute to society.

headline.main: In Japan, Golden Years Have Lost Their Glow

docs.abstract: Japanese elderly are finding that nation's economic malaise and demographic changes are taking glow off retirement years; Japan, with birthrate at record low, is graying faster than any other industrialized nation, straining pension systems; supply of second jobs for retirees is shrinking; tradition of oldest child caring for parents is breaking down as more young people live in cities under severe space constraints; government is working hard to spur opportunities for retirees to be productive; photos (special section, Retirement) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE MIDWEST PROTEST IN MICHIGAN Some black leaders in Detroit are urging the city's largely Democratic residents to vote for Senator John McCain in the Michigan primary on Tuesday to embarrass Gov. John Engler, a staunch supporter of Gov. George W. Bush. The Rev. Wendell Anthony, president of the Detroit chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., and State Representative LaMar Lemmons III said Mr. Engler had not supported moves to help Detroit retain its tax base. Michigan Democratic caucuses are in March. Robyn Meredith (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALONG with the good news that Americans are living longer comes the sobering prospect that many will lose the ability to take care of themselves. And long-term care -- whether in a nursing home, in an assisted-living center or in one's own home -- can be frightfully expensive. A year in a nursing home, for example, can cost more than $100,000 in New York City; the national average is almost $50,000. An apartment or room in an assisted living center, with health professionals on hand, can easily run to $30,000, and care at home can be even more costly.

headline.main: The Insurance You Really Hope You Will Never Need

docs.abstract: Advice on long-term-care insurance to pay for care in nursing home, assisted-living center or own home; table of largest providers (special section, Retirement) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SEVEN years ago, Rosemary Bakker received a dreaded phone call: her aging mother had fallen, broken a hip and needed to be hospitalized. As upsetting as that was, Ms. Bakker soon found that more trouble lay ahead. ''My mother lives alone in a single-family house in Brooklyn,'' she said. ''When she got home from the hospital she couldn't walk without assistance. I could hardly breathe watching her struggle with a walker -- in pain, on medication -- trying to maneuver over doorsills, getting caught in area carpets and extension cords. She couldn't bend to get food out of the refrigerator or reach pots and pans. There wasn't even a bathroom on the first floor. Suddenly, the house that had suited her well for 42 years became a time bomb just waiting to go off.''

headline.main: Taking the Dangers Out of Hanging Around the House

docs.abstract: Donna Wilkinson article on interior design changes and products to make homes safe environment for older adults; key issue is avoiding falls, leading danger in home; designer Rosemary Bakker cites importance of proper lighting and flooring; photos (special section, Retirement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1966, Medicare was created with a noble ambition: to provide health care coverage for America's elderly. In practice, advocates for the elderly will tell you, Medicare falls far short of paying for the health care most people need. ''As good as Medicare is, it covers only about half the health care costs of people who go on it,'' said Diane Archer, the president of the Medicare Rights Center, a New York-based nonprofit organization that assists people on Medicare.

headline.main: Making Your Way Through the Maze of Medicare Options

docs.abstract: Larry Katzenstein article on getting most from Medicare coverage; explains basic choices and reasons for making them, or not making them; photos (special section, Retirement) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of last year, Gov. George Pataki and New York State legislative leaders approved a commendable new program called Family Health Plus to provide coverage for uninsured low-income parents and other adults. But now the governor is battling with the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, and the Democrat-controlled Assembly over how that program is to be financed. The program will provide insurance to low-income parents, much like Child Health Plus, a program for low-income children. It would cover families with incomes of up to 150 percent of the poverty line, thus providing help for a family of four earning up to about $25,000 a year. It would also provide coverage for individuals without children who are within the existing poverty level. The federal government will pay roughly half the cost of the program, or about $700 million, over the next three and a half years, with the state paying the other $700 million.
docs.abstract: Editorial opposes Gov George E Pataki's contention that New York City should pay half of state's $700 million cost for Family Health Plus, program that will provide coverage for uninsured low-income parents and other adults; holds that there is no reason that state cannot carry full burden

docs.lead_paragraph: Reversing a policy that dates back almost a decade, one of the nation's largest insurers has decided to stop paying for a grueling and controversial breast cancer treatment that has not been proved to work. In recent days, the company, Aetna/US Healthcare, has been informing doctors that it will no longer provide reimbursements for the treatment -- bone marrow transplants for women with breast cancer -- for its 1.6 million members.

headline.main: Insurer Drops a Therapy for Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Aetna/US Healthcare, reversing policy that dates back almost decade, decides to stop paying for bone marrow transplants for women with breast cancer--controversial treatment that has not been proved to work (M)

byline.original: By GINA KOLATA and KURT EICHENWALD

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's largest chain of psychiatric hospitals lies in tatters. More than half of the roughly 90 hospitals and treatment centers operated by Charter Behavioral Health Systems will soon be closed and the company is expected to announce as early as today that it is seeking bankruptcy protection. Three years ago, officials of a real estate investment trust headed by Richard E. Rainwater, the financier based in Fort Worth, announced a $400 million investment that they said would breathe new life into Charter. But rather than revitalizing the chain, the deal contributed to its collapse, according to many former Charter officials, undermining patient care in the process.

headline.main: A Price Too High?; Deal to Save Charter Behavioral May Have Harmed It

docs.abstract: Charter Behavioral Health Systems, nation's largest chain of psychiatric hospitals, will close more than half of roughly 90 hospitals and treatment centers and is expected to announce that it is seeking bankruptcy protection; three years ago, officials at Crescent Real Estate Equities headed by Richard E Rainwater announced $400 million investment that they said would breathe new life into Charter; but rather than revitalizing chain, deal contributed to its collapse, undermining patient care in process; company says Charter's problems were caused by insurance cutbacks, not by 1997 plan, and that patient care was not affected; plan saddled Charter Behavioral, unit of Magellan Health Services Inc, with some $125 million in franchise fees and rapidly escalating rents; Magellan's former chief executive Mac Crawford received $2.48 million bonus when he agreed to sell half of company to Crescent Real Estate; other top executives got stock options; Magellan then began collecting large franchise fees from Charter; eventually, it transferred its remaining stake in Charter to Crescent Operating Inc, created by Crescent Real Estate to hold equity stake in Charter because real estate investment trusts are prohibited by law from operating companies; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's largest chain of psychiatric hospitals lies in tatters. More than half of the roughly 90 hospitals and treatment centers operated by Charter Behavioral Health Systems will soon be closed and the company is expected to announce as early...

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 7, when Liana Gedz was rolled into the operating room at Beth Israel Medical Center for a Caesarean section, life at the hospital's obstetrics and gynecology department seemed to be back on track at last. The unit, a target of the State Health Department following the death of a patient in 1997, was as busy as ever, delivering nearly 5,500 babies a year. A new department chairman, Dr. Daniel Saltzman, was widely viewed as raising the quality and accountability of his subordinates.

headline.main: At Beth Israel, Lapses in Care Mar Gains in Technology

docs.abstract: Article, noting case in which Dr Allan Zarkin carved in his initials in belly of patient, Dr Liana Gedz, after delivering baby by Caesarean section, contends that once again Beth Israel's obstetrics unit has spelled disaster for hospital that has busily promoted gains in medical technology; Zarkin's case has put obstetrics department under microscope of NYS Department of Health for second time in two years; hospital officials say that unlike case of Lisa Smart's death in 1997, where systematic failures were found, latest case does not reflect any institutional problems; Dr Daniel Saltzman, chairman of hospital's obstetrics department, comments; photo (M)
